Frequently Asked Questions
What should I contact my MP about?
There are many reasons you may wish to contact me – from personal issues you may be facing, to questions about policy
How long does it take to hear back from you?
Due to the large number of emails, letters and phone calls each day, I will try and respond to you as quickly as possible. Please note that all communications, including emails, are dealt with in the order in which they are received.
We currently have a significant volume of casework coming in, and whilst we generally aim to get back within two weeks, at present it will take significantly longer.
Have you included your full home address? If not please re-send your email including this information in order to receive a response. This is requested even if you email frequently.
When are your constituency surgeries?
My constituency surgeries usually take place on Saturdays.
Please check my Facebook and Instagram account for the latest updates on when and where my surgeries are taking place.
If you would like to book a slot then please email matthew.brown@parliament.uk
Is it possible to visit you in Parliament?
Yes, please contact my team to discuss organising a meeting.
Please email george.pickthorn@parliament.uk
Can I contact Perran even if he isn't my MP?
Parliamentary Protocol prevents an MP from dealing with enquiries form another MP’s constituency, so be sure that you are a constituent of Camborne and Redruth, as contacting the wrong representative can cause delays to your case.
You can check online here: FindYourMP
If your query relates to a Local Authority issue then please direct your correspondence directly to your locally elected Cornwall Councillor.
To find your local representative please visit: MyLocalCouncillor

Preventing folk from starving and freezing is the greatest immediate challenge we face from 13 years of Conservative failure. Having knocked on thousands of doors across Camborne, Redruth, Hayle, the issue of most concern to voters is how they are going to feed and heat themselves and their families. Over the last decade we have seen a steady erosion of household disposable income. The Conservative government had lost control of inflation, and too many working people are in insecure, low wage jobs. Our new Labour government will have to tackle this issue as a matter of priority, head on.
As the new MP for Camborne, Redruth and Hayle, I managed to persuade a Conservative-led Council to declare a Food Poverty Emergency, including a number of key commitments that will ensure that no one in the area should go hungry. In opposition, rather than pointless petitions, practical action to deal with the worst excesses of Conservative failure is what is required in areas such as Close Hill, Treleigh, Pengegon and East Pool Park. In Government, as your Labour MP, I am fighting to ensure that the principle of ‘no one goes hungry’ is at its core.

Born and raised in Redruth, it is my privilege to serve the people of Camborne, Redruth and Hayle to the best of my ability.
My policy priorities and stances as MP for Camborne, Redruth & Hayle
Jobs in the green economy
Economic rejuvenation should be based on maximising sustainable energy resources to create secure, well-paid jobs. The opportunities in Cornwall are immense, and I am determined that Camborne, Redruth and Hayle will be at the centre of what I hope to be a Green Industrial Revolution
